site_name: Capital of Texas Zoo L L C

citations.narrative:
The animal inventory and acquisition /disposition records could not be located by the licensee at time of the inspection.
Dealers and exhibitors shall maintain records or forms that include information about animals in their possession including
offspring born. Records shall include information about animal acquisition and disposition. The dealer and or exhibitor
shall maintain a copy of these records.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At time of the inspection, numerous flies were observed swarming on turtle food that had been left in the enclosure
housing the pair of ringtail Lemurs with the infant. Flies are also an issue in the enclosure housing 2 brown lemurs as they
were swarming on the ground around the food container of primate biscuits. Flies may spread disease and cause
discomfort to the animals. There is no pest control program in place around these animal enclosures. A safe and effective
pest control program shall be established and maintained to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce
contamination by pest in animal areas.
To be corrected by 8/17/2023.

There are numerous sharp points that are protruding from the hot wire on the side of the hippo enclosure. There is a mass
of tangled hot wire located next to the gate at the hippo shelter. The sharp points and the tangled wire are areas that may
cause injury to the hippo. Sharp point and tangled wire must be repaired or removed to provide a safe enclosure that
protects the hippo from injury.

There are discarded items (paint cans, old tools, tarps and shade cloth) around several animal exhibits including the male
serval and hippo enclosures. Trash is littering the area around the dry food storage container. Discarded materials, empty
food containers and other trash serve as an attractant and breeding area for pests such as rodents, snakes and flies
which may spread disease, contaminate food and harm the animals. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated
areas and cleared as often as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
ELIZABETH PANNILL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The animal inventory and acquisition /disposition records could not be located by the licensee at time of the inspection. 
Dealers and exhibitors shall maintain records or forms that include information about animals in their possession including 
offspring born. Records shall include information about animal acquisition and disposition. The dealer and or exhibitor 
shall maintain a copy of these records. 
3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
At time of the inspection, numerous flies were observed swarming on turtle food that had been left in the enclosure 
housing the pair of ringtail Lemurs with the infant. Flies are also an issue in the enclosure housing 2 brown lemurs as they 
were swarming on the ground around the food container of primate biscuits. Flies may spread disease and cause 
discomfort to the animals. There is no pest control program in place around these animal enclosures. A safe and effective 
pest control program shall be established and maintained to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce 
contamination by pest in animal areas. 
To be corrected by 8/17/2023. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
There are numerous sharp points that are protruding from the hot wire on the side of the hippo enclosure. There is a mass 
of tangled hot wire located next to the gate at the hippo shelter. The sharp points and the tangled wire are areas that may 
cause injury to the hippo. Sharp point and tangled wire must be repaired or removed to provide a safe enclosure that 
protects the hippo from injury. 
3.131(c)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
There are discarded items (paint cans, old tools, tarps and shade cloth) around several animal exhibits including the male 
serval and hippo enclosures. Trash is littering the area around the dry food storage container. Discarded materials, empty 
food containers and other trash serve as an attractant and breeding area for pests such as rodents, snakes and flies

which may spread disease, contaminate food and harm the animals. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated 
areas and cleared as often as necessary to protect the health of the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ELIZABETH PANNILL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
